normalised: Load shedding. Those two words strike fear into the heart of every Indian, from M U M B A I to Manipur. It's basically the polite term for planned power outages, and it’s become a frustratingly familiar part of life. Remember those summer evenings in Lucknow, when the power would go out right in the middle of your favourite episode of "Taarak Mehta Ka Ooltah Chashmah"? Yeah, load shedding.

normalised: So, what’s the deal? Well, it’s all about demand and supply, bhai. India's power grid is a complicated beast, trying to balance the energy needs of billions. When demand exceeds the available power supply – especially during peak hours like those sweltering afternoons when everyone's A C is blasting – the electricity distribution companies (Discoms) have to resort to load shedding to prevent a complete system collapse. Think of it like a pressure valve; better to let a little steam out than have the whole cooker explode.

normalised: The reasons for the power shortage can be many. It could be a heatwave driving up demand, a problem at a power plant (maybe a coal shortage at the N T P C plant near Delhi), or even just plain old infrastructure issues like outdated transmission lines. Sometimes, it's even blamed on theft and "power pilferage," as they politely call it in official reports. Imagine your neighbour, Sharmaji, tapping into your electricity line – multiplied by thousands!
